conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to calculate the work done by the frictional force on the object as it moves along the conveyor belt.
The conveyor belt is moving clockwise at a speed of 6 m/s. The distance between the two drive wheels M and N is 10 m. An object with mass 3 kg is placed directly above wheel M.
The coefficient of kinetic friction between the object and the conveyor belt is 0.3, and g = 10 m/s².
The object starts at point M with an initial velocity of 0 and moves to point N on the conveyor belt.
The acceleration a can be found using the formula a = v / t, where v = 6 m/s and g = 10 m/s².
The distance L is given as L₁ = 10 m.
The frictional force can be calculated using the formula F = μmg, where μ = 0.3, m = 3 kg, and g = 10 m/s².
The work W done by the frictional force is given by W = F × d, where d is the distance traveled by the object.
Substitute the values into the work formula: W = μmg × L, W = 0.3 × 3 × 10 × 10.
The work done is calculated as W = 90 J.
The work done by the frictional force on the object is 90 J.
